2808.66.text:
but you can buy hydrates
of cyclopropenone,

2815.92.text:
There's nothing that
exotic about that.

2817.72.text:
It massively prefers
to exist as the adduct

2820.80.text:
and it massively does not
want to exist as the ketone.

2824.29.text:
And this is the effect of ring
stringing, if you look at it,

2827.10.text:
the intrinsic preference for
a hydrate for a carbon atom

2831.65.text:
that has force substituents,
this wants to be 109 degrees.

2835.46.text:
A carbon with four
different substituents.

2839.11.text:
If you look at a carbon atom
that has three substituents,

2841.96.text:
like this, that carbonyl
group wants to be 120 degrees.

2845.92.text:
And in this case, because
it's a cyclopropane ring,

2848.43.text: it doesn't get to be either.

2850.44.text:
The fact is, that when you've
got three carbons bonded

2852.62.text:
to each other, all those
angles are 60 degrees.

2855.59.text:
And all these angles
are 60 degrees.

2857.99.text:
So it's basically a
matter of which sucks less.

2863.87.text: It sucks less to be like this.

2866.48.text:
At least 109 is closer
to 60 than 120.

2869.51.text:
And so cyclopropenone,
again, you can't buy that.

2874.38.text:
You can only buy acetyls
of cyclopropenone.

2879.59.text:
Okay so I'm going to go
ahead and stop right there,

2883.68.text:
and when we come back, I'll
talk about various ring sizes

2891.09.text:
versus free acetone
and then we'll talk

2895.60.text:
about some other types
of pi star systems.
